title: Application-specific graph drawings
synopsis: Graphs and graph drawings arising in other areas of application include

title: Book from the Ground
synopsis: Book from the Ground is an artwork and book published by MIT Press, which uses visual symbols collected over seven years, to tell a story in a visual language ([[Pictograph]] anyone can understand - [http://mitpress.mit.edu/books/book-ground mitpress.mit.edu]

title: Centrality measures
synopsis: Information about the relative importance of nodes and edges in a graph can be obtained through [[centrality]] measures, widely used in disciplines like [[sociology]].

title: Changes to this Site
synopsis: Below we list recent changes to this site only without also listing changes from the [[Neighbourhood]]:

title: Currently Working On
synopsis: Some pages that I am currently working on. You way want to check out my other sites for things I write about.

title: Cytoscape
synopsis: There are some great docs - [http://js.cytoscape.org/#cy.center js.cytoscape.org]

title: Cytoscape.js
synopsis: Cytoscape.js is an open-source graph theory (a.k.a. network) library written in JavaScript. You can use Cytoscape.js for graph analysis and visualisation - [http://js.cytoscape.org/ cytoscape.org]

title: DAG
synopsis: In mathematics and computer science, a [[directed acyclic graph]] (DAG), is a finite directed graph with no directed cycles - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Directed_Acyclic_Graph wikipedia]

title: Dagre
synopsis: Dagre is a JavaScript library that makes it easy to lay out directed graphs on the client-side - [https://github.com/cpettitt/dagre/wiki github]

title: Data Visualisation
synopsis: Here we look at tools for data visualisation for [[Platform Earth]] and wiki.

title: Directed Acyclic Graph
synopsis: In mathematics and computer science, a directed acyclic graph ([[DAG]]), is a finite directed graph with no directed cycles - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Directed_Acyclic_Graph wikipedia]

title: Directed graph
synopsis: In mathematics, and more specifically in graph theory, a directed graph (or digraph) is a graph that is a set of vertices connected by edges, where the edges have a direction associated with them - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Directed_graph wikipedia]

title: Displaying Graphviz SVG
synopsis: Here we look at how we might display interactive graphs using the [[svg]] export option from [[Graphviz]].

title: DOT language
synopsis: The DOT Language

title: Drawing Graphs as Maps
synopsis: The visualisation of complex multidimensional relationships as geographic maps is a powerful way to combine notions of clustering and topological relationships in an intuitive and playful way.

title: Fedwiki Tools
synopsis: Here we list a few tools that are of particular use in managing and creating [[Fedwiki]] content. Check [[Recycled pages]] to find delted pages.

title: Gephi
synopsis: Gephi is an open-source network analysis and visualization software package written in Java on the NetBeans platform - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gephi wikipedia]

title: GMap Algorithm
synopsis: GMap is an algorithm for visualizing graphs as maps. GMap (see also [[GvMap Algorithm]]), is a practical tool for visualizing relational data with geographic-like maps. It aims to capture the underlying structural information, clustering, and neighborhoods of complex data  - [http://www.graphviz.org/Documentation/GHK09.pdf pdf]

title: Graph database
synopsis: In computing, a graph database is a database that uses graph structures for semantic queries with nodes, edges and properties to represent and store data - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_Database wikipedia]

title: Graph drawing
synopsis: Graph drawing is an area of mathematics and computer science combining methods from geometric graph theory and information visualization to derive two-dimensional depictions of graphs arising from applications such as social network analysis, cartography, linguistics, and bioinformatics - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_drawing wikipedia]

title: Graph theory
synopsis: In mathematics, and more specifically in [[graph theory]], a tree is an [[undirected graph]] in which any two vertices are connected by exactly one path. In other words, any acyclic connected graph is a tree. A forest is a disjoint union of trees - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tree_(graph_theory) wikipedia]

title: Graph Visualisation Software
synopsis: Here we look at various tools, [[software]] and frameworks that we can use to visualise graphs for [[Liquid Democracy]].

title: Graphical conventions
synopsis: Graphs are frequently drawn as '''node-link diagrams''' in which the vertices are represented as disks, boxes, or textual labels and the edges are represented as [[line segment]]s, polylines ([[Polygonal chain]]), or curves in the [[Euclidean plane]]. Node-link diagrams can be traced back to the 13th century work of [[Ramon Llull]], who drew diagrams of this type for [[complete graph]]s in order to analyze all pairwise combinations among sets of metaphysical concepts.

title: GraphML
synopsis: GraphML is an XML-based file format for graphs. The GraphML file format results from the joint effort of the graph drawing community to define a common format for exchanging graph structure data. It uses an XML-based syntax and supports the entire range of possible graph structure constellations including directed, undirected, mixed graphs, hypergraphs, and application-specific attributes - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GraphML wikipedia]

title: Graphoid Service
synopsis: Graphoid (git repo) is a node.js service that converts a graph definition into a static PNG image using the same [[Vega]] library code that runs in advanced browsers. Graphoid is used as a fallback for non-JS enabled/compatible browsers - [https://wikitech.wikimedia.org/wiki/Graphoid wikitech.wikimedia.org]

title: Graphviz
synopsis: Graphviz (short for Graph Visualization Software) is a package of open-source tools initiated by AT&T Labs Research for drawing graphs specified in [[DOT language]] scripts - [http://graphviz.org/ graphviz.org]

title: Graphviz Idioms
synopsis: I make the same sort of diagrams over and over. Here I list fragments of dot code that have proven useful. [http://graphviz.org/ website]

title: Graphviz in El Dorado
synopsis: I've had trouble combining clickable graphviz in complex applications. I've made it work in El Dorado which is a Sinatra app available as open source. [https://github.com/newrelic/el-dorado-ui github]

title: GvMap Algorithm
synopsis: GvMap is an algorithm for visualizing graphs as maps. It is part of the [[Graphviz]] library, and was originally called the [[GMap Algorithm]].

title: HTML Image maps
synopsis: Client-side image maps were introduced in HTML 3.2, and do not require any special logic to be executed on the server (they are fully client-side). They also do not require any JavaScript - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Image_map wikipedia]

title: Javascript Graph Libraries
synopsis: Dagre (Directed graph renderer for Javascript) - [https://github.com/cpettitt/dagre github.com]

title: Layout methods
synopsis: *In [[force-based layout]] systems, the graph drawing software modifies an initial vertex placement by continuously moving the vertices according to a system of forces based on physical metaphors related to systems of springs ([[spring (device)]]) or [[molecular mechanics]]. Typically, these systems combine attractive forces between adjacent vertices with repulsive forces between all pairs of vertices, in order to seek a layout in which edge lengths are small while vertices are well-separated. These systems may perform  [[gradient descent]] based minimiz

title: Linked Data
synopsis: In the Federation linked-data has then benefit of being able to be aggregated form a range of sources in a manor that is logically consistent and can provide sophisticated processing and reasoning.

title: Liquid Democracy
synopsis: Liquid Democracy is a marriage between [[Direct Democracy]], and [[Representative Democracy]]. It aims to create a more flexible and fluid way for people to express their [[Democratic Preference]].

title: Liquid Graph Theory
synopsis: Both [[Federated Wiki]]'s and [[Liquid Democracy]] share the same need: to be able to visualise the network of connections.

title: Maps
synopsis: Here we look at how to work with maps in wiki. In particular we want to look out how we can use wiki to create and document walks, oral histories, and map festivals.

title: Merkle tree
synopsis: In cryptography and computer science, a hash tree or Merkle tree is a tree in which every non-leaf node is labelled with the hash of the labels or values (in case of leaves) of its child nodes. Hash trees allow efficient and secure verification of the contents of large data structures. Hash trees are a generalization of hash lists and hash chains - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Merkle_Tree wikipedia]

title: Neo4J
synopsis: Neo4j is an open-source graph database implemented in Java and accessible from software written in other languages using the Cypher query language through a transactional HTTP endpoint -

title: Neo4J Resources
synopsis: This graph database has worked well enough that we want to be good at applying it. There are documents that might help.

title: Network Visualisation
synopsis: He we list a few pages and sites about graph and network visualisation as it relates to [[FedWiki]].

title: Pictograph
synopsis: Pictograph is a nice term that I feel we can abuse to describe graphical representations of articles and wiki pages. It is a synonym for [[Pictogram]].

title: Pretty Wiki
synopsis: Pretty wiki is a minimal rendering of wiki, without the wobble, or clutter of the journal. It is a deferential design of wiki that emphasises reading - a way to publish content from [http://livecode.world/pretty_wiki.html wiki]

title: Python Graph Libraries
synopsis: Here are some quick links about graphing using python

title: Quality measures
synopsis: Many different quality measures have been defined for graph drawings, in an attempt to find objective means of evaluating their aesthetics and usability. In addition to guiding the choice between different layout methods for the same graph, some layout methods attempt to directly optimize these measures.

title: Related Visualization
synopsis: We're interested in new kinds of visualization and new ways to make them.

title: Research Activity
synopsis: On this page you can find [[research groups]] that are working on topics related to the current [[domain]]:

title: Simulation
synopsis: Simulation is the imitation of the operation of a real-world process or system over time. The act of simulating something first requires that a model be developed; this model represents the key characteristics, behaviors and functions of the selected physical or abstract system or process. The model represents the system itself, whereas the simulation represents the operation of the system over time - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simulation wikipedia]

title: Software
synopsis: Here we review at the latest graphing software:

title: SVG
synopsis: [[Smallest Federated Wiki]] is able to display SVG files in the image plugin in the normal way. The resulting images take up far less disk space than their raster (jpeg or png) counterparts.

title: SVG Drop Events
synopsis: Below are a collection of links imported from [[OneTab]]. You can view these links here - [https://www.one-tab.com/page/UxD8LRpvRmCf1aaRFAtGIQ one-tab.com]:

title: SVG Image Map
synopsis: We can now embed interactive [[svg]]s in wiki.

title: Technology Sites
synopsis: A list of sites that document technology related to the [[Smallest Federated Wiki]]

title: TinkerPop
synopsis: [[TinkerPop]] is not a graph DB, it's a graph software stack / computing framework for graph DBs (OLTP) and graph analytic systems (OLAP).

title: Topic Maps
synopsis: Topic Maps is a standard for the representation and interchange of knowledge, with an emphasis on the findability of information - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topic_Maps wikipedia]

title: Tree (graph theory)
synopsis: In mathematics, and more specifically in [[graph theory]], a tree is an [[undirected graph]] in which any two vertices are connected by exactly one path. In other words, any acyclic connected graph is a tree. A forest is a disjoint union of trees - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tree_(graph_theory) wikipedia]

title: Tulip (software)
synopsis: Tulip is an information visualization framework dedicated to the analysis and visualization of relational data. Tulip aims to provide the developer with a complete library, supporting the design of interactive information visualization applications for relational data that can be tailored to the problems he or she is addressing - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tulip_(software) wikipedia]

title: Ushahidi
synopsis: Ushahidi, Inc. is a non-profit software company that develops free and open-source software (LGPL) for information collection, visualisation, and interactive mapping.

title: Vega
synopsis: Vega is a visualization grammar, a declarative format for creating, saving and sharing interactive visualization designs.

title: Visualisation Activity
synopsis: View all activity from the [[Visualisation Sites]] roster below:

title: Visualisation Sites
synopsis: Here we list sites related to [[data visualisation]], [[graph visualisation]], and [[mapping]].

title: Visualising Graphs
synopsis: On this site we collect links, code and ideas about how we can visualise and navigate graphs.

title: Visualising the Federation
synopsis: Here we look at how we might visualise the [[Federation]], and explore using [[Cytoscape]] to achieve a scaleable ability to visualise the network of links and in particular [[Network of Forks]] relevant to a particular writing context.

title: Visualization Is Coming Of Age
synopsis: It has not really been possible until very recently to represent large interactive graphs visually, and especially not on the web.

title: Visualizing Page History
synopsis: As can be seen by [[Understanding Page History]] this can be complex, containing differing view points - and maybe realities.

title: Vizzuality
synopsis: Vizzuality is a science and technology company focused on data visualization, web-GIS and tool development and committed to working on projects related to conservation, the environment and sustainable development. They have two offices, in Madrid and Cambridge - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vizzuality wikipedia]

title: Wards GraphViz Work
synopsis: I've mostly used the dot component of the suite of graph rendering programs.

title: WebGL Examples
synopsis: Here we list some WebGL examples that play well in a modern browser:

title: Welcome Visitors
synopsis: Welcome to this [[Federated Wiki]] site where we explore techniques and software for [[Visualising Graphs]].

title: Wrap Data with Visualisation
synopsis: The [[Smallest Federated Wiki]] is designed around the idea of data, or [[Linked Data]] to eb precise. Every paragraph, that is every item in a wiki panel or [Wiki Story] is data (a [[JSON Object]]).

title: Global Database of Events, Language, and Tone
synopsis: The Global Database of Events, Language, and Tone ([[GDELT]]), created by Kalev Leetaru of Yahoo! and Georgetown University, along with Philip Schrodt and others, describes itself as:

title: GDELT
synopsis: GDELT is the largest, most comprehensive, and highest resolution open database of human society ever created. GDELT stands for [[Global Database of Events, Language, and Tone]] and descries itself as:

title: Visualisation Projects
synopsis: Here we list projects involved or specialising in graph and data visualisation:

title: United Nations Global Pulse
synopsis: UN Global Pulse is an innovation initiative of the United Nations to harness big data, artificial intelligence and other emerging technologies for sustainable development and humanitarian action. Global Pulse works through a network of regional innovation labs, known as Pulse Labs, and with partners to build and implement solutions and to provide policy guidance and technical assistance for mainstream adoption of innovation. - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Nations_Global_Pulse wikipedia]

title: Integrated Conflict Early Warning System
synopsis: The Integrated Conflict Early Warning System (ICEWS) combines a database of political events and a system using these to provide conflict early warnings. It is supported by the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency in the United States. The database as well as the model used by Lockheed Martin Advanced Technology Laboratories are currently undergoing operational test and evaluation by the United States Southern Command and United States Pacific Command. - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integrated_Conflict_Early_Warning_System wikipedia]

title: The Good Judgment Project
synopsis: The Good Judgment Project (GJP) is a project "harnessing the wisdom of the crowd to forecast world events". It was co-created by Philip E. Tetlock, decision scientist Barbara Mellers, and Don Moore. It was a participant in the Aggregative Contingent Estimation (ACE) program of the Intelligence Advanced Research Projects Activity (IARPA) in the United States. Predictions are scored using Brier scores. The top forecasters in GJP are "reportedly 30% better than intelligence officers with access to actual classified information." - [https://en.wikipedia.org/

title: Plotly
synopsis: Plotly lets users easily create interactive charts and dashboards to share online with their audience.

title: Charts
synopsis: Here we look at how we might use existing services to make beautiful and dynamic graphs and charts.

title: Observable
synopsis: Observable is a new way to write interactive [[simulation]]s in the browser. It looks like a pragmatic, powerful and simple way to implement many of the ideas of [[Bret Victor]] today in a modern web app.
